snippet: No single group can muster enough territory or popularity to win an increasingly fragmented war, or even to negotiate and enforce an eventual peace.
abstract: News Analysis; deeply entrenched conflict in Syria makes it difficult to see how nation can avoid disintegrating into de facto spheres of influence ruled by warring factions; Islamic State has consolidated power in nation's eastern half, while Nusra Front and other insurgent groups have staked out territory in the northwest and south; American-backed Kurdish militias are attempting to expand semiautonomous areas in the northeast, while Pres Bashar al-Assad has shifted focus to protecting his holdings from Damascus to Mediterranean coast.

byline.contributor: Thomas L. Friedman and Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: No single group can muster enough territory or popularity to win an increasingly fragmented war, or even to negotiate and enforce an eventual peace.

headline.print_headline: Syria Is Disintegrating Into Fragmented Parts Under Pressure of War
headline.main: Syria Increasingly Disintegrates in Crucible of War

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
